A fundamental concept of Gibson’s ecological approach to perception-action is that of 2 affordance (J. J. Gibson, 1979). Affordances are opportunities for action as higher order, emergent 3 relations in the animal-environment system (Stoffregen, 2003a). That is, affordances emerge from 4 the multifaceted relationship or fit between animal and environment. In any given situation, there 5 are a multitude of affordances (i.e., a field of affordances; see Bruineberg & Rietveld, 2014). Which 6 of the multitude of affordances are perceived as well as whether, when, and how any of these 7 affordances are actualized depend on the intentions of the animal (Shaw & Kinsella-Shaw, 1988)—8 specifically the overarching goal(s) to be achieved and the behavior(s) required to do so. 9
However, behaviors are not performed in isolation. Achieving a given overarching goal 10 typically requires that a particular set of behaviors be performed in a particular way given a 11 particular set of circumstances. That is, behaviors are both nested within other behaviors (over 12 multiple spatial and temporal scales) and within the goals for which and circumstances under 13 which those behaviors occur. Consequently, affordances for a given behavior are nested within 14 other affordances (over multiple spatial and temporal scales, Stoffregen, 2003b) and within the 15 goals for which and the context within in which those affordances are perceived (Bingham & 16 Muchisky, 1995). 17 Depending on the overarching goal to be achieved, the set of behaviors required to achieve 18 that outcome can be performed sequentially, simultaneously or in parallel (i.e., simultaneously but 19 independently of one another). Consequently, depending on the particular goal-directed behavior 20 to be performed, the set of affordances for behaviors that yield the intended outcome can likewise 21 be perceived sequentially, simultaneously or in parallel (Mark et al., 2015). Moreover, perceiving, 22 or actualizing a given affordance can influence what affordances are subsequently perceived or 23 actualized (Ye et al., 2009). This implies that a given affordance can be superordinate to (of higher-24 order than) or subordinate to (of lower-order than) another (Wagman et al., 2016a). That is, higher-25 order affordances may emerge from the relationship between lower-order affordances (Peker, 26 Böge, Bailey, Wagman & Stoffregen, in press). 27
as a means-ends hierarchy (Vicente & Rasmussen, 1990; Wagman et al., 2016a, but see 2 discussion of a possible alternative heterarchical organization in the Discussion section). According 3 to Vicente & Rasmussen (1990), each level of the hierarchy includes a set of affordances that 4 relate to the why, what and how of performing a behavior. At any level of the hierarchy, 5 affordances are simultaneously and mutually constrained by the other levels, rather than in a strict 6 top-down fashion. In this conceptualization, the behavior itself (e.g., using a ladder) is performed at 7 the (intermediate) ‘what’ level. This level represents the specific behaviors to be performed but 8 does not represent either the goals for which they are being performed or the means by which they 9
could be performed. The superordinate (why) level relates to the goals of the behavior— why one 10 engages in this behavior (e.g., retrieving an object)—but does not prescribe the specific behaviors 11 necessary to achieve that goal. The subordinate (how) level, on the other hand, relates to means 12 by which the behavior can be carried out (e.g., stepping). In addition, in this conceptualization, 13 perceiving affordances for a given behavior does not correspond to perceiving affordances for a 14 specific sequence of behaviors but rather to a field of possibilities that generalizes beyond any 15 particular sequence (Wagman et al., 2019). That is, perceiving affordances for a given behavior 16 simultaneously reflects affordances nested at both lower and higher levels of the hierarchy. 17 In many (if not all) cases, affordances emerge from a multifaceted fit between the animal’s 18 action capabilities and the substances, surfaces, places, objects, and events that comprise the 19 animal’s niche (see Richardson et al., 2008). Consequently, the same substances, surfaces, 20 places, objects, and events may or may not afford the same behavior for two different animals 21 (even of the same species) depending on the specific action capabilities of each animal (Fajen, 22 2008). 23 Action capabilities (and hence, perception of affordances) are determined, in part, by an 24 animal’s anthropometric properties. For example, Warren (1984), found that (perception of) the 25 boundary between stairs that afford climbing and those that do not could be expressed as a body-26 scaled ratio of 0.88 between leg length and step height. However, action capabilities are also 27 determined by more dynamic properties such as strength, coordination, and balance. Accordingly, 28

defined as the process of progressively detecting patterns in lawfully structured energy arrays that 10 provide increasingly useful information about a given affordance. In other words, performing a 11 given behavior for a given overarching goal under a particular set of circumstances requires that an 12 animal detect information about a very particular multifaceted fit between animal and environment 13 (Jacobs & Michaels, 2007). The more complex the goals for which a given behavior is being 14 performed and the more complex the circumstances under which that behavior is being performed, 15 the more specific the information about that fit becomes. Additionally, given that any given goal can 16 be achieved by a variety of different behaviors, and any given behavior can be performed in a 17 variety of different ways, a given goal-directed behavior can be performed in multiple ways and by 18 multiple means. This means that performing a goal-directed behavior requires flexibly and 19 temporarily recruiting potentially independent anatomical components into a smart—task-specific—20 device capable of achieving the goal-directed goal (Bingham, 1988; Runeson, 1977). 21 Consequently, successfully performing a given goal directed behavior requires that animals 22 precisely scale choices about whether, when, and how to perform a given behavior to their action 23 capabilities (Fajen, 2007). The process that establishes and maintains the scaling between action 24 (and perception) and information about a given affordance to make such choices is known as 25 calibration (Withagen & Michaels, 2005). Of course, perceiving and acting capabilities change over 26 both the short term and long term. In many cases, such changes require recalibration—learning a 27 new scaling relationship between information about affordances for a given behavior and whether, 28
Franchak, 2017). 2 In general, studies indicate that perception of affordances for a given behavior increasingly 3 reflect an animal’s action capabilities as they become attuned to (as they learn to detect) the 4 information about a given affordance (Fajen & Devaney, 2006). Moreover, as animals learn to 5 detect more useful information about a given affordance, they can learn (become calibrated to) 6 how to use that information to more precisely scale choices about whether, when, and how to 7 perform that behavior and they can relearn (recalibrate) how to do so when circumstances change 8 (Fajen, 2005). For instance, experience in a given perception-action task typically leads a 9
perceiver toward detecting and exploiting increasingly useful informational variables that enable 10 increasingly fine-tuned perceiving and behaving (Jacobs et al., 2000, 2001; Jacobs & Michaels, 11 2002, 2007). 12 In this respect, it could be argued that over the course of long-term practice, experts in a 13 given perception-action task (1) have learned to detect more useful information about task-specific 14 affordances than novices (Araújo et al., 2005), (2) have become more precisely calibrated to how 15 use such information to perform such tasks. It could also be argued that given more finely 16 developed abilities to detect information about task-specific affordances coupled with more finely 17 developed abilities to exploit such information about task-specific affordances, experts in a given 18 perception-action task also have (3) more finely developed abilities to perceive task-specific action 19 boundaries than do novices. 20 Given that experts have highly developed abilities to detect and exploit information about 21 task-specific affordances, they are better able to use (1) many different coordination patterns to 22 perform a given task-specific behavior over the short term and (2) many different behavioral 23 patterns (i.e., many different nestings of coordination patterns) to achieve a given task-specific 24 overarching goal over the long term. In other words, experts can re-organize multiple degrees of 25 freedoms at multiple levels and over multiple time scales to achieve consistent performance 26 outcomes (Seifert et al., 2016). In the biological systems literature, the ability of structurally 27 different elements to yield same outcome is known as degeneracy (Edelman & Gally, 2001). 28

As an example, Seifert et al. (2021) found that expert 4 climbers exhibited variable behavioral patterns both within and between bouts of climbing. In a 5 climbing task involving nested affordances, participants were asked to touch or grasp a rock-6 climbing hold in a number of different ways: (1) by either moving their hand or the foot first; (2) by 7 using either a face-on or side-on body position to the wall; and (3) by using multiple the support 8 points. These findings 11 suggest that the nesting of affordances allows climbers to exploit degeneracy and open up new 12 possibilities for climbing. One way to investigate the nesting of affordances is through the person-13 plus-object-system. 14 Tool-use 15 In everyday life, the objects used in the course of performing many goal-directed activities 16 change the action capabilities of the animal and thereby alter the fit between animal and 17 environment. An object attached to or held by an animal creates an integrated person-plus-object 18 system with a unique sets of action capabilities and control dynamics. Such objects simultaneously 19 increase action capabilities for some tasks (e.g., the ability to reach distant objects) and decrease 20 them for other tasks (e.g., the ability to fit through narrow spaces). Therefore, animals must be able 21 to perceive how an attached or held object changes the task-specific affordances for performing a 22 given goal-directed behavior over the short term and for achieving multiple overarching goals over 23 the long term. That is, perceiving affordances of and for the person-plus-object system should 24 require the same processes of attunement, calibration and recalibration as are required for 25 perceiving affordances for the person without such an object. To this end, it is important to 26 consider person-plus-object system as a spontaneously assembled smart instrument (see Carello, 27 Fitzpatrick, Domaniewicz, et al., 1992; Runeson, 1977). Doing so means that (1) a given person-28
object system can be assembled over many different anatomical structures, and (3) many different 2 person-plus-object systems can be assembled over the same anatomical structures. 3 A large body of research has explored the presumption that the information that supports 4 perceptual capabilities with respect to the person-plus-object system is defined over the invariant 5 patterns of deformation of the body’s muscular and connective tissues that occur when 6 manipulating the attached or held object. Therefore, perceiving affordances of and for the person-7 plus-object system should require the same processes of attunement and calibration to information 8 in making choices about whether, when, and how to perform a given behavior with or with respect 9
to the person-plus-object system. 10

Despite sustained interest in the topic of affordances and the ubiquity with which objects 12 are held by or attached to an animal in the course of performing everyday behavior, an 13 understanding of perception of affordances of and for the person-plus object system is still 14 emerging (see Mangalam et al., 2022). Moreover, no systematic review of this topic was available 15 at the time of our search. Based on this body of literature, this systematic review aims to establish 16 the state of science regarding the perception of affordances of and for the person-plus-object 17 system. The central research questions in this systematic review are related to how humans 18 become attuned to the information about affordances of and for the person-plus-object system and 19 calibrate their actions to such information. To answer this question, we discuss the scientific 20 literature in two main categories. The first set of studies that we reviewed were those examining 21 attunement: these studies investigated the detection of informational variables that support 22 perception of affordances for the person-plus-object system, in particular, how such detection 23 changes with practice. The second set of studies we reviewed were those examining calibration 24 and recalibration: these studies focus on the degree to which perceived action boundaries on a 25 given behavior reflect the actual action boundaries on that behavior, and in particular, how this 26 relation changes with practice. Then we make suggestions for future research and how those 27 processes could be understood as being organized heterarchically (as opposed to hierarchically). 28
Eligibility 2 Studies were included in the systematic review if (1) they included healthy human 3 participants; (2) they investigated perception of affordances (implicitly or explicitly) of or for the 4 person-plus-object system; (3) they used physical objects (rather than a virtual object or an image 5 of an object); (4) they were experimental studies (if there was manipulation of an independent 6 variable); (5) the study referred to attunement, calibration or recalibration; (6) were published in an 7 English-language peer-reviewed journal as an original full-length paper (i.e., not a review or 8 conference paper). 9
Search strategy 10 Literature search and selection were carried out according to the Preferred Reporting Items 11 for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) (Moher et al., 2009). The initial search was 12 conducted in November 2021, with additional searched carried out in January 2023. A three-step 13 procedure was used to identify relevant studies. First, we selected Pubmed, APA PsychArticle and 14 Psychology and Behavioural Sciences Collection as relevant databases to identify studies that met 15 the inclusion criteria summarized above. Each search was structured to include two sets of terms; 16 the first set relating to the person-plus-object system: object, wear, tool-use, handheld, altered 17 body, locomotion, dynamic touch; and the second set relating to ecological psychology: affordance, 18 perception-action coupling, ecological approach, ecological psychology, body-scaled, action-19 scaled, attunement, calibration, recalibration. The terms included within each of these collections 20 were separated with the operator ‘OR’, while the two collections of terms were linked with the 21 operator ‘AND’. All possible variants of words like ‘change’ and ‘decrease’ were entered in 22 databases. We included the title, abstract, keywords, and topic as search areas. To further identify 23 relevant studies, we reviewed the reference lists and citation of all studies identified in step one. 24 The titles and abstracts of all papers retrieved via the systematic search strategy were exclusively 25 screened by the first author (PV) based on the outlined inclusion criteria. Next, the remaining full-26 text studies were screened using the same inclusion criteria. 27 Quality assessment 28

Each category contains a number of attributes, which are marked as present, 8 absent, or not applicable and are scored on a scale from 0 to 5. The scores for the eight categories 9

As the CCAT protocol does not provide a specific protocol for interpreting 11 the score, and as each category does not have the same weight, the range of possible scores for 12 each category was divided in terciles, with articles assessed as exhibiting either; i) low (0-1); ii) 13 moderate (2-3); or high (4-5) methodological quality; then a global score was generated as the sum 14 of all the categories and was expressed as a percentage (for another example of systematic review 15 using the CCAT, see van Andel et al., 2017). and decreased the critical point. 2 Discussion 3 Main findings 4 Attunement 5 The results of this systematic review highlighted for attunement that: (1) individuals learn to 6 detect information about a particular affordance for the person-plus-object system; (2) objects that 7 are (or might be) attached to the body create a multiplicity of affordances for the person-plus-object 8 system, requiring that the person choose which affordances to exploit and how to exploit them and; 9
(3) perception of affordances for the person-plus-object system reflects how affordances are 10 nested within the context of a particular task. 11 Information pick-up. Recent work suggests that objects attached to or held by the body 12 become experienced as part of the body; therefore, the attunement should be with respect to 13 information about affordances for the person-plus-object system. The results of our review are in 14 line with this claim: studies showed that individuals perceive nested affordances for the person-15 plus-object system by detecting, attuning to, and calibrating action to information about such 16 affordances. 17 Given that the information about a given affordance is invariant over transformation, 18 individuals are able to detect information about a given affordance in different energy arrays by 19 means of different perceptual systems. In addition, studies have shown that individuals exploit 20 information about performing task-specific behaviors. In short, the information about affordances 21 for the person-plus-object system seems to be dependent on a particular task but independent of a 22 particular energy array. 23 By definition, affordances of any kind are emergent (or higher-order) relations within the 24 animal-environment system (Stoffregen, 2003a). These higher order relations differ from the 25 animal or environment components that comprise them. The same ought to be true for affordances 26 for the person-plus-object system—that is, the higher order affordances for the person-plus-object 27 system ought to differ from those for the person or of the object. In general, the results of the 28
review suggest that the individual does not perceive the isolated properties that make up the 2 system, such as the length of their arms or of the object itself, but rather he or she perceives the 3 affordances for the person-plus-object system as such. Along similar lines, studies have shown 4 that improvement in the perception of affordances for the person-plus-object-system is 5 independent from improvements in perception of the properties that compose it. 6 Multiplicity of affordances. Generally, many different objects can be used to achieve the 7 same goal and the same object can be used to achieve many different goals. The multiplicity of 8 affordances gives rise to the questions of both intention (because perception of opportunities for 9 action is goal-directed and involves choices) and object design (because objects will always have 10 multiple affordances even if they are designed for a specific purpose). It has been shown that 11 intention guides the detection of relevant informational variables that support perception of 12 affordances. And, of course, the affordances of manufactured objects are constrained by the 13 design of those objects. Thus, objects always afford multiple behaviors, and the individual must 14 choose from among these to achieve the intended goal. On one hand, designing objects to afford a 15 limited set of particular behaviors would facilitate the detection and exploitation of information 16 about this particular set of affordances of that object, but doing so may make more difficult to 17 detect and exploit information about other affordances. On the other hand, designing objects that 18 afford many different behaviors would allow facilitate the detection and exploitation of information 19 about many different affordances but may make it more difficult to (quickly) detect and exploit 20 information about a particular affordance. Therefore, objects with a complex design could offer 21 multiple affordances which would entail that sets of behaviors nested over spatial and temporal 22 scales are specific to the goal-directed task. Future studies should take this property into account. 23 Relation between affordances. One fruitful framework for understanding relationships 24 among affordances in performing a goal-directed task under a particular set of circumstances, is 25 that of a means-ends hierarchy (Vicente & Rasmussen, 1990; see Wagman et al., 2016a). The 26 results of the studies included in this review are consistent with sensitivity to the nesting relations 27 among affordances in such a hierarchy (but should be considered subordinate to a broader 28
or create objects so as to perform a given behavior in the context of both the overarching goal and 2 the underlying circumstances. For example, assembling a tool for use in a given task required 3 participants to perceive affordances for the assembled tool both before and while it was being 4 assembled. That is, participants had to create higher-order affordances for the person-plus-object 5 system by exploiting lower order affordances (Wagman et al., 2016b). Consequently, performing 6 any goal-directed behavior entails perceiving (and thus detecting information about) affordances 7 for nested behaviors. However, attunement to information about a given (nested) affordance is 8 often insufficient for successful performance of a goal-directed behavior. In addition, individuals 9
must also calibrate their actions to that information. 10 Calibration 11 The results of this systematic review highlighted that: (1) exploration is associated with (and 12 often necessary for) improved calibration and or recalibration; (2) individuals quickly recalibrate to 13 changes brought on by an object attached to or held by the body; (3) calibration to a given 14 affordance for the person-plus-object system can bring about functionally equivalent changes in 15 perception of other affordances for the person-plus-object system. 16 Exploration for calibration. Exploration (i.e., moving so as to facilitate detection of 17 invariant patterns in ambient energy arrays) generates information about the animal-environment 18 system, including the person-plus-object system. According to the studies included in this review, 19 the degree of calibration is related to the ability of the individual to explore ambient energy arrays 20 via movements, even movements as subtle as postural sway. The more constraints on exploratory 21 movement, the less the individuals were able to calibrate to changed action capabilities. Although 22 generation and pick-up of information can occur during actions that are not explicitly exploratory 23 (see Hacques et al., 2021), exploration to achieve the goal facilitates calibration improvement 24 and/or recalibration. 25 Action boundaries. To perform a goal-directed behavior successfully and safely, 26 individuals must be sensitive to the boundaries of their action capabilities for performing that 27 behavior (Fajen, 2007). Objects attached to or held by the body modify the action capabilities and 28
sensitive to how an object attached to the body changes their action capabilities (and thus changes 2 affordances for) a particular task. However, this may depend on the specifics of both the object and 3 of the task (Higuchi et al., 2004; Yasuda et al., 2014) and future studies should expand this area of 4 research. 5 In terms of the relation between perceived action capabilities, individuals were able to 6 maintain the same ratio (between perceived:maximum and actual:maximum) for affordances for 7 the person-plus-object system as for the person (without the object), highlighting the ability to 8 quickly recalibrate after a period of practice. Results included in this review indicated recalibration 9 to new action capabilities was facilitated with task-relevant experience and developmental changes 10 in action capabilities, especially into early adulthood. However, recalibration to changed action 11 capabilities is sometimes less well facilitated, either because of more conservative choices or 12 because of declines in action capabilities. Overall, task-specific experience and expertise seems to 13 lead to a better calibration or recalibration, but it remains unclear whether this is due to a decrease 14 in the variability of behaviors that the individuals can perform, to a better awareness of action 15 boundaries, to greater maximal action capabilities, or to some combination of these. 16 Functional equivalence. As highlighted previously, an object can be used to achieve 17 several different goals, but a given goal can also be achieved by several different means or by 18 means of using several different objects (i.e., relating to functional equivalence). Experiments have 19 shown that two different (by functionally equivalent) means of reaching can bring about functional 20 equivalent changes in perception of affordances for reaching for the person-plus-object system. In 21 addition, in some circumstances, calibration of perception of affordances for performing a given 22 behavior by one particular means transfers to perception of affordances for performing that 23 behavior by a different means. 24 However, even though two objects may be used to achieve functionally equivalent ends, 25 this does not necessarily mean that using those objects requires equivalent degrees of effort or 26 ability. How individuals make decisions among those means is not well understood, particularly 27 when functional equivalence could be observed and reflect skilled behavior Thus, skilled behavior 28

sections.heading: Future research directions 6
sections.text:
By reviewing the research on attunement and (re)calibration processes with respect to the 7 person-plus-object system, our findings emphasized how the perception of affordances of an 8 object attached to or held by the body facilitates the performance of functional equivalent behaviors 9
in achieving the task goal. However, everyday behaviors are often considerably more complex (as 10 several degrees of freedom must be coordinated to act synergistically) than simple lab-based 11 activities, and it is unclear whether the results of such studies would be transferable to more 12 complex situations. Thus, there is a lack of research investigating complex richly nested behaviors, 13 particularly in relation to the unique control dynamics of the person-plus-object system and the 14 many degrees of freedom involved in performing complex tasks. 15 In addition, investigating how the particular design of an object would offer multiple (nested) 16 affordances depending on the skill of the individual would be of great interest to better design 17 objects (Pagano et al., 2021) and to develop skill acquisition programs. Obviously, the ability of an 18 individual to perform successful behaviors will vary depending on their action capabilities and how 19 the object changes these action capabilities. This is an important focus for future research, 20 especially for professions that require expertise such as athletes, firefighters, or military.
